chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: For this problem, we first need to differentiate the types of markets:

**Weak form efficient markets** do not reflect the available information as well as the insider information on the stock price

**Semi-strong form efficient markets** prices the stocks based on the available information to the public.

**Strong form efficient markets** reflect both the available information and the insider information on the price of the markets.

**a.** In this situation, the profit opportunity lies on (2) since the market is weak form efficient. This is where the profit is since in the other scenarios, the price is already reflected by the available information so there is no room for profit there since the future price is already predicted.

**b.** The profit can be found in case (1) and (2) since in these scenarios, the prices do not reflect the information. This means that you can still assess whether the declared information of the companies will be profitable.

**c.** All the scenarios except (4) can be profitable. Since the senior members of the company board are buying stocks, it may mean that there is insider information that is not yet reflected in the price. Thus, a strong form efficient market in this case is not profitable since this type of market reflects all information, both public and private, to the price of the stock.
